{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3549365,"name":"Emmett Sisson","username":"emmettds","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/e/13edae/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-06T15:44:30.580Z","cooked":"

Less of a plea for help (but I will gladly welcome advice) and more curiosity: what do teams specifically do to get their elevator to travel between setpoints so smoothly? Obviously there’s PID tuning and a motion profile as well as high build quality, but what’s the general thought process and implementation that happens? Is it just repeated testing and adjusting over and over again?

My team is running a two-stage Thrifty elevator on an X60. We’re tuning Motion Magic to try and polish the movement between the pre-set encoder values, but going from a higher level down to a lower one is a lot more jarring/aggressive than going up. Overall the travel is clunky, slow, and somewhat scary with the sounds it makes. I’m interested in learning how a team might approach their own mechanism in terms of refining it to the level of fluidity I’ve been seeing.

Crazy impressed with how stunning the robots are looking this season – good luck to those I might see at FiM Mt. Pleasant this weekend!!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-03-06T15:44:30.580Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":39,"reads":363,"readers_count":362,"score":272.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":494492,"topic_slug":"how-do-you-guys-make-your-elevators-so-insanely-smooth","display_username":"Emmett Sisson","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65766,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-do-you-guys-make-your-elevators-so-insanely-smooth/494492/1","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3549368,"name":null,"username":"Kabinet","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kabinet/{size}/244566_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-06T15:46:17.355Z","cooked":"

The difference on the way down makes me think you need to tune your gravity feedforward.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-03-06T15:46:17.355Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":357,"readers_count":356,"score":101.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":494492,"topic_slug":"how-do-you-guys-make-your-elevators-so-insanely-smooth","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57616,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4476 Software / Drive Team"},"post_url":"/t/how-do-you-guys-make-your-elevators-so-insanely-smooth/494492/2","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3549369,"name":"John Bottenberg","username":"John_Bottenberg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/john_bottenberg/{size}/224569_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-06T15:46:37.000Z","cooked":"
emmettds:

going from a higher level down to a lower one is a lot more jarring/aggressive than going up

I haven’t used Motion Magic, but I believe this could be fixed by adding a feed-forward term to counteract the force of gravity. This should at least make up and down movements have the same level of jarringness/aggressiveness.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-03-06T15:47:10.562Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":355,"readers_count":354,"score":76.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":494492,"topic_slug":"how-do-you-guys-make-your-elevators-so-insanely-smooth","display_username":"John Bottenberg","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12266,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3142, 8706, 714←4973←2930←3322←67"},"post_url":"/t/how-do-you-guys-make-your-elevators-so-insanely-smooth/494492/3","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3549370,"name":"Tom Line","username":"Tom_Line","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_line/{size}/236809_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-06T15:48:40.806Z","cooked":"

Also, when you are moving your elevator up, check what velocity you are really reaching. Set that as your max velocity. Make sure you are actually reaching your specified acceleration value as well. You can do all this easily in tuner. If your mechanisms are moving outside the values you have set, it can make it look very rough when it tries to correct it suddenly.

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Tuning a Vertical Elevator with Motion Profiling

In this section, we will tune a simple position controller for a vertical elevator. In addition, we will discuss the advantages of using motion profiling for this situation. About the Profiler: A M...

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-03-06T15:50:25.779Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":337,"readers_count":336,"score":127.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":494492,"topic_slug":"how-do-you-guys-make-your-elevators-so-insanely-smooth","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/advanced-controls/introduction/tuning-elevator.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Tuning a Vertical Elevator with Motion Profiling — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":39}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/how-do-you-guys-make-your-elevators-so-insanely-smooth/494492/5","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3549422,"name":"Aidan McMaster","username":"AMcMaster","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/cab0a1/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-06T16:42:18.935Z","cooked":"

some lessons/practices I’ve learned ab designing and running elevators in order of importance:

  1. tight tolerances are your friend, the better, tighter, and more consistent you can make your clearance between the bearings and the tubes the better. too much slop and you’ll get rocking and the dreaded racking (rotational twisting of the stages within themselves

  2. rigidity, the less your system can flex and flop the better. If it is not solid you will get swaying and whipping (especially an issue with sideways elevators)

  3. pulley/rope placement, as you raise the elevator and the pulleys get closer to each other, the angle of your rope gets worse. if not rigged/designed properly there will be a point where the rope is nearing horizontal and you will not have enough force to move the system any more

  4. distributed load between stages, if your carriage is far heavier than the other stages or vice versa it is hard to tune as the force required to raise the system drastically changes as each stage gets to the top of travel (CF springs are a good fix for this)

  5. good controller tuning, the smoother you can be the faster you can move. aggressive accelerations and decelerations are hard on parts. you can get pretty fancy with feedforward/motion profiling control, but its not required to be smooth, it enables you to run faster

  6. rope tension, too loose is bad, too tight is bad. and the tension will change over time due to rope stretching

A common theme on these considerations is minimizing friction in the system. The less static friction you have the less you have to yank on everything to get it moving.

Hopefully something here helps or gets you going down the right path. I am also very interested in hearing other ways to make elevators better.
